Definition 1 (Configuration space / universe).

Definition


  • The configuration space is usually denoted Ω\Omega. As indicated by its name, the set Ω\Omega contains all the possible configurations of a probabilistic model.

  • Its elements are usually denoted ω\omega, and we will call them ’elementary configurations’.

Warning : the name of the space Ω\Omega and its elements ω\omega vary according to contexts and languages. Ω\Omega is often called the ’sample space’ or ’universe’, and the elements ω\omega ’samples’,’outcomes’ or ’realizations’.

Examples (1)


Probabilistic models are very useful to analyse dice rolls and card games. What is a relevant configuration space

  • to model a dice roll ?

  • to model 22 dice rolls ?

  • to model nn dice rolls ? What is the size of this configuration space?

Examples (2)


Assume that 𝒮\mathcal{S} is a 5252 card deck and that we are interested in modeling an experiment where a player draws cards from the card game. What should we chose as configuration space when

  • the player draws one card ?

  • the player draws one card, puts it back and draws another card ?

  • the player draws two cards without putting them back ?

Assume a player draws nn cards without putting them back in the deck. What is the size of the smallest configuration space describing the possible results ?

Note that when using Cartesian products, we have (a,b)≠(b,a)(a,b)\neq (b,a). The order between the card draws is taken into account. In card games, the order in which cards are drawn is often not important. In that case, when drawing 22 cards, we have (a,b)∼(b,a)(a,b)\sim (b,a).

If we do not distinguish results up to permutations, what is the size of the configuration space when

  • the player draws one card ?

  • the player draws nn cards without putting them back ?

Examples (3)


In this course we are particularly interested in signal and image processing problems.

What are the relevant configuration spaces when studying

  • real signals observed on 10001000 points ?

  • continuous real signals of duration 11 second ?

  • 256×256256\times 256 color images ?

Definition 2 (Events).

Definition


An event AA is a subset of the configuration space Ω\Omega: A⊂ΩA\subset \Omega.

Remark: a more precise definition requires the notion of σ\sigma-algebra. The next ’Remark’ node gives the definition of σ\sigma-algebras, but the notion will not be used in the rest of the course.

Examples


  • for the dice roll, the configuration space is Ω={1,2,3,4,5,6}\Omega = \{1,2,3,4,5,6\}, the subset A={2,4,6}A=\{2,4,6\} is an event. AA is often defined as ’the number is even’.

  • when Ω\Omega is a 5252 card deck, ’the card is a diamond’, ’the card is a 22’, are typical events.

  • when Ω=ℝ1000\Omega=\mathbb{R}^{1000} is a set of signals, the event {0}×ℝ999\{0\}\times \mathbb{R}^{999} describes all the signals starting with 00.

Remark 2 (Events and σ\sigma-algebra).

Introduction


Earlier, events have been defined as subsets A⊂ΩA\subset \Omega. When Ω\Omega is not a finite set, some mathematical problems can appear, and not every subset A⊂ΩA\subset \Omega is considered to be an event. For instance when Ω=ℝ\Omega = \mathbb{R}, events are subsets of ℝ\mathbb{R} which can be constructed ’easily’ from intervals. For instance A=⋃i∈ℕ[i2,i+12]A= \bigcup_{i\in \mathbb{N}} \left[\frac{i}{2},\frac{i+1}{2}\right] is an event. Its probability is given by the sum of P([i2,i+12])P\left([\frac{i}{2},\frac{i+1}{2}]\right). On the other hand, it is possible to define complicated sets which cannot be expressed from intervals. Using the axioms of probability, we cannot compute the probability of such sets from the probability of intervals. Hence we exclude them from events.

Definition


The events are the subsets of Ω\Omega on which we define probability values. The set of events is called the σ\sigma-algebra. In order to be consistent with the probability calculus, the σ\sigma-algebra 𝒜\mathcal{A} on Ω\Omega must satisfy the following axioms:

  • Ω∈𝒜\Omega \in \mathcal{A} (→\rightarrow axiom 1 of probabilities)

  • A∈𝒜⇒Ac∈𝒜A \in \mathcal{A} \Rightarrow A^{c}\in \mathcal{A} (→\rightarrow consequence 1 of probabilities)

  • if Ai∈𝒜A_i\in \mathcal{A} for i∈ℕi\in \mathbb{N}, then ⋃i∈ℕAi∈𝒜\bigcup_{i\in \mathbb{N}} A_i \in \mathcal{A} (→\rightarrow axiom 3 of probabilities)

Examples


  • When Ω\Omega is finite the σ\sigma-algebra is usually 𝒫(Ω)\mathcal{P}(\Omega): every subset of Ω\Omega is an event.

  • when Ω=ℝ\Omega= \mathbb{R}, the σ\sigma-algebra is obtained by taking countable unions of intervals and their complements.

data.text:
Remark 3 (Assignment of probabilities).
To model real life situations, we assign probabilities to events that reflect what we know about the situation. The probabilities on the configuration space Ω\Omega are usually assigned according to one of the two following principles.

  • Indistinguishability. Assume that in a certain experiment, the elements of Ω\Omega are perfectly indistinguishable. The probability of an event AA is then given by the number of configuration kk in which it occurs (ω∈A\omega \in A) divided by the total number of configuration nn: kn\frac{k}{n}. It is for instance the case when we draw a card from a card game without seeing what is on the card: they are all indistinguishable.

  • Probabilities as frequencies. Assume that an experiment that produces output value in Ω\Omega has been repeated nn times. If kk of the output values belongs to the event AA, the probability assigned to AA is the number kn\frac{k}{n}. This can be used to evaluate the probabilities of the outcomes of an asymmetrical die. We will come back to the link between probabilities and frequencies later in the course.

Independently from how they are assigned, probability values should verify several rules.
data.summary: Remark 3 (Assignment of probabilities). Probability values are usually assigned either on the basis of a criterion of indistinguishability or from the observed frequencies of a repeated experiment.
data.title: Assignment of probabilities

Definition 3 (Probability).

Definition


A probability PP is a function which takes in input an event and returns a positive real number. It must verify the following axioms:

  • axiom 1: P(Ω)=1P(\Omega) = 1

  • axiom 2: P(A⊂Ω)≥0P(A\subset \Omega) \geq 0

  • axiom 3: if A∩B=∅A\cap B=\emptyset then P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B) (also true for countable sums)

Direct consequences:

  • consequence 1:P(Ac)=1−P(A)P(A^c) = 1-P(A)

  • consequence 2 :P(∅)=0P(\emptyset) = 0

  • consequence 3:P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(A∩B)P(A\cup B) = P(A)+P(B)-P(A\cap B)

Interpretation


The probability gives a notion of ’size’ to events. Given that the size of Ω\Omega is 11, the size of events can be interpreted as the proportion they occupy in Ω\Omega. Hence, the PP of probability can also be read as the PP of proportion.

Assume that a die is a perfect cube. All faces are indistinguishable from each other, except for the written number. In this case, it is relevant to assign probabilities according to the indistinguishability principle:

P({1})=16,P({2})=16,P({3})=16,P(\{1\}) = \frac{1}{6}, P(\{2\}) = \frac{1}{6},P(\{3\}) = \frac{1}{6}, P({4})=16,P({5})=16,P({6})=16.P(\{4\}) = \frac{1}{6},P(\{5\}) = \frac{1}{6},P(\{6\}) = \frac{1}{6}.

The distribution is called uniform. It is now possible to compute the probability of every event, using the axiom 3 (if A∩B=∅A\cap B=\emptyset then P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B)):

P({2,4,6})=P({2}∪{4}∪{6})=P({2})+P({4})+P({6})=12.P\left(\{2,4,6\}\right) = P\left(\{2\}\cup\{4\}\cup \{6\}\right)=P(\{2\})+P(\{4\})+P(\{6\})=\frac{1}{2}.

Assume now that our die is a bit damaged. It is no longer perfectly symmetrical. Hence, we can no longer use the principle of indistinguishability. In that case a relevant approach is to roll the die many time and to assign probabilities according to the frequency of apparition of the numbers.

P({1})=k1N,P({2})=k2N,P({3})=k3N,P(\{1\}) = \frac{k_1}{N}, P(\{2\}) = \frac{k_2}{N},P(\{3\}) = \frac{k_3}{N}, P({4})=k4N,P({5})=k5N,P({6})=k6N.P(\{4\}) = \frac{k_4}{N},P(\{5\}) = \frac{k_5}{N},P(\{6\}) = \frac{k_6}{N}.

Exactly as before, the probability of other events is calculated with the rule ’if A∩B=∅A\cap B=\emptyset then P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B)’.

Definition 5 (Random variables).

Introduction


Introduce first the idea behind the definition. Build a configuration space representing the possible ages of 22 persons. A natural choice is Ω=ℝ×ℝ\Omega = \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R} where the first coordinate represents the possible ages of the first person,and the second represents the possible ages of the second person (Ω=ℝ+×ℝ+\Omega = \mathbb{R}_+ \times \mathbb{R}_+ is also a natural choice).

The coordinate function age1:Ω→ℝage_1:\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R},

age1(ω=(ω1,ω2))=ω1age_1\left(\omega=(\omega_1,\omega_2)\right)=\omega_1

’extracts’ the age of the first person out of an elementary configuration ω\omega. Similarly, the coordinate function age2:Ω→ℝage_2:\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R},

age2(ω=(ω1,ω2))=ω2age_2\left(\omega=(\omega_1,\omega_2)\right)=\omega_2

’extracts’ the age of the second person. The functions age1age_1 and age2age_2 are called random variables.
The coordinates functions age1age_1 and age2age_2 extract interesting quantities from the elementary configuration. However, there are other interesting quantities which are not coordinate functions. For instance, for an elementary configuration ω\omega, we can be interested in the average age of the 22 persons. We can define the function average:Ω→ℝaverage:\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R},

average(ω=(ω1,ω2))=ω1+ω22average\left(\omega=(\omega_1,\omega_2)\right) = \frac{\omega_1+\omega_2}{2}

The function averageaverage is also called a random variable.

Definition


A random variable XX taking values in a space EE is a function X:Ω→EX:\Omega\rightarrow E. In particular, integer random variables are functions X:Ω→ℕX:\Omega\rightarrow \mathbb{N} and real random variables are functions X:Ω→ℝX:\Omega\rightarrow \mathbb{R}.

Remark: this is a simplified version of the true definition which requires random variables to be ’measurable functions’ that is to say : when AA is in the σ\sigma-algebra of EE, X−1(A)X^{-1}(A) must be in the σ\sigma-algebra of Ω\Omega.

Example 1


Consider the following dice rolling game. If the number is even, the player wins 11 euro, and if the number is odd he loses 11 euro. The function Gain:Ω={1,2,3,4,5,6}→{−1,1}Gain:\Omega=\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}\rightarrow \{-1,1\}, G(1)=G(3)=G(5)=−1G(1)=G(3)=G(5)=-1 G(2)=G(4)=G(6)=1G(2)=G(4)=G(6)=1 is a random variable.

Example 2: coordinate random variables


Assume that we roll a dice nn times. The configuration space that describes all the possible outcomes is Ω={1,2,3,4,5,6}n\Omega = \{1,2,3,4,5,6\}^n. Let XiX_i be the ii-th coordinate function on Ω\Omega. For instance,

X1((3,2,3,...,6))=3.X_1\left( (3,2,3,...,6) \right) = 3. These random variables ’extract’ the result of the ii-th roll out of the elementary configuration. We can also construct the random variables Gaini=Gain∘XiGain_i = Gain \circ X_i: the gain at the ii-th roll.

Definition 6 (Law of a random variables).

Introduction


Let Ω\Omega be a configuration space with a probability PP, and XX be a random variable taking values in a set EE. Recall that PP is a function that takes in input an event of Ω\Omega and associates its probability. The random variable transports the probability PP to the set EE. The probability of a set AA in EE is determined by the probability of the inverse image of AA in Ω\Omega.

Definition


The law of PXP_X of the random variable X:Ω→EX:\Omega \rightarrow E is a probability on EE defined by PX(A⊂E)=P(X−1(A)).P_X(A \subset E) = P\left(X^{-1}(A)\right). It is called the law of the random variable XX.
Remarks:

  • instead of PX(A)P_X(A), we often write P(X∈A)P(X\in A) (the probability that the value of the random variable XX falls in AA).

  • EE can be viewed as another configuration space with a probability PXP_X

In the previous game, the random variable Gain:Ω={1,2,3,4,5,5}→{−1,1}Gain:\Omega=\{1,2,3,4,5,5\}\rightarrow \{-1,1\}, Gain(1)=Gain(3)=Gain(5)=−1Gain(1)=Gain(3)=Gain(5)=-1 Gain(2)=Gain(4)=Gain(6)=1Gain(2)=Gain(4)=Gain(6)=1 induces a probability distribution on {−1,1}\{-1,1\}. We have PGain({−1})=P(Gain−1({−1}))=P({1})+P({3})+P({5})P_{Gain}(\{-1\}) = P(Gain^{-1}(\{-1\}))=P(\{1\})+P(\{3\})+P(\{5\}) PGain({1})=P(Gain−1({1}))=P({2})+P({4})+P({6}).P_{Gain}(\{1\}) = P(Gain^{-1}(\{1\}))=P(\{2\})+P(\{4\})+P(\{6\}).

Definition: cumulative distribution


Let XX be a real random variable (E=ℝE=\mathbb{R}). The probability PXP_X can be represented by its cumulative distribution FX:ℝ→ℝF_X:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}, defined by

FX(a)=PX(]−∞,a]).F_X(a) = P_X\left(]-\infty,a]\right).

All the information on PXP_X is contained in FXF_X. Since the cumulative distribution is a function ℝ→ℝ\mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}, sometimes it is conceptually simpler to manipulate FXF_X than the probability itself which is a function from the subsets of ℝ\mathbb{R} to ℝ\mathbb{R}.

  • How do we compute PX(]a,b])P_X(]a,b]) from FXF_X?

  • What do we know about limx→∞FX(x)\lim_{x\rightarrow \infty} F_X(x) ?

  • Can we have x<yx<y and FX(x)>FX(y)F_X(x)>F_X(y)?

  • If for x∈[0,1]x\in [0,1], FX(x)=xF_X(x)=x, what is PX([2,3])P_X([2,3])?

Definition: density of a real random variable


Let XX be a real random variable. Sometimes, the law of XX admits a density. When it exists, the density of XX is a function fXf_X such that

PX([a,b])=∫abfX(x)dx.P_X([a,b]) = \int_a^b f_X(x)dx.

Remark: we defined the cumulative distribution and density of a ’random variable’ but note that it depends on XX only through the probability PXP_X. Hence the density can be defined for a probability PP on ℝ\mathbb{R} even if it is not defined as the law of a random variable.

Exercises


For a real random variable XX,

  • show that ∫−∞+∞fX(x)dx=1\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}f_X(x)dx=1

  • show that fX=(FX)′f_X=(F_X)'.

data.text:
Remark 4 (Abstract configuration space).

Most probability problems of this course start by defining a configuration space Ω\Omega and a probability PP on it. Though, many real life problems involving probabilities make no mention of the space Ω\Omega.

Example: weather


Assume that we want to predict the wind speed SS in Marseille. Since we know that the wind speed is related to the temperature TT, we can attempt to predict the wind speed from the temperature. The wind speed is a vector of ℝ3\mathbb{R}^3 and the temperature is a positive number, hence our problem can be fully modeled by the configuration space Ω1=ℝ3×ℝ+\Omega_1 = \mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathbb{R}_+. From a database of measurements, we can estimate the probability of an elementary configuration by P1({(s,t)})=n(s,t)nP_1(\{(s,t)\})=\frac{n_{(s,t)}}{n}, where n(s,t)n_{(s,t)} is the number of times (s,t)(s,t) has been measured and nn is the total number of measurements. With the law P1P_1, it is possible to calculate the conditional probability (which we will define later) of the wind speed given the temperature. With this conditional probability, it is possible to say what is the most probable value of wind speed for a temperature.

Now assume that temperature is a poor predictor of wind speed: given a temperature, the probability over wind speed has a high variance. In order to improve our analysis, it is common to incorporate new parameters in our model. We could, for instance consider the atmospheric pressure PrPr. The new configuration space would then be Ω2=ℝ3×ℝ+×ℝ+\Omega_2 = \mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathbb{R}_+ \times \mathbb{R}_+, with probability P2P_2. Luckily, given a temperature and a pressure, the probability on the wind speed has a small variance.

Otherwise, we could incorporate more and more parameters, and consider new configuration spaces. In practice, instead of changing the configuration space each time we want to add a parameter, we treat the parameters as random variables of a larger configuration space. At a given moment, all the meteorological parameters are a function of the positions and speeds of the particles, which could be described by the configuration space Ω=(ℝ3×ℝ3)N\Omega = (\mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathbb{R}^3)^N, where NN is the number of particles. Wind speed, temperature, and air pressure are functions of the type Ω→ℝd\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^d, hence they are random variables.

In practice, evaluating and manipulating a probability PP on the positions and velocities of each particles is unrealistic. Though only the joint law of the studied variables matters, in our case the joint law P(S,T,Pr)P_{(S,T,Pr)} of the random variable (S,T,Pr):Ω→ℝ3×ℝ+×ℝ+(S,T,Pr):\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathbb{R}_+ \times \mathbb{R}_+. Technically speaking, ℝ3×ℝ+×ℝ+\mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathbb{R}_+ \times \mathbb{R}_+ is no longer referred to as a configuration space, given that additional parameters may be included in our analysis. Note that the precise form of Ω=(ℝ3×ℝ3)N\Omega = (\mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathbb{R}^3)^N is not particularly helpful. It is only necessary to know that the relevant parameters are functions on Ω\Omega. In this context, the term ’universe’ to refer to Ω\Omega is particularly appropriated.

Moral


In practice, the general configuration space Ω\Omega and its probability are often not precisely described, or even mentioned. In these cases, what matters is the joint probability law of the variables of interest.

Definition 13 (Independent events).

Motivation


Consider again 22 dice rolls with a uniform probability distribution PP. Consider the two events

  • ’AA’: {6}×{1,..,6}\{6\}\times \{1,..,6\}, the first roll is 66. P(A)=16P(A)=\frac{1}{6}

  • ’BB’: {1,..,6}×{6}\{1,..,6\}\times \{6\}, the second roll is 66. P(B)=16P(B)=\frac{1}{6}

Remember that conditional probabilities are given by

P(B|A)=P(A∩B)P(A)=P({(6,6)}){6}×{1,..,6}=16P(B|A) = \frac{P(A\cap B)}{P(A)} = \frac{P(\{(6,6)\})}{\{6\}\times \{1,..,6\}}=\frac{1}{6}

Hence P(B)=P(B|A)P(B)=P(B|A): the probability of getting 66 on the second roll is the same as the probability of getting 66 on the second roll knowing that the first roll was a 66. We say in that case that the event BB does not depend on the event AA. Reversing the conditioning in the formula shows that AA is also independent of BB.

Definition


Two events AA and BB are called independent when

P(A∩B)=P(A)P(B)P(A\cap B) =P(A)P(B)

Interpretation


When P(A)>0P(A)>0: the proportion of B∩AB\cap A in AA is the same as the proportion of BB in Ω\Omega

P(B∩A)P(A)=P(B)P(Ω)=P(B).\frac{P(B\cap A)}{P(A)} = \frac{P(B)}{P(\Omega)}=P(B).

In other words, conditioning probabilities to the event AA does not change the probability of BB.

When P(B)>0P(B)>0, the same can be said about the proportion of A∩BA\cap B in BB.

Example


Let Ω\Omega be the 5252 card deck with uniform distribution PP. Show that the events ’the card is a diamond’ and ’the card is an ace’ are independent.

and

14×113=152,\frac{1}{4} \times \frac{1}{13} = \frac{1}{52},

𝐏({(x1,...,xn)})=P({x1})P({x2})..P({xn}).\bm P(\{(x_1,...,x_n)\}) = P(\{x_1\})P(\{x_2\}) .. P(\{x_n\}).

If PP has a density ff, the joint density 𝐟\bm f is

𝐟((x1,...,xn))=f(x1)f(x2)..f(xn).\bm f((x_1,...,x_n)) = f(x_1)f(x_2) .. f(x_n).

In the modelling of the repetition of nn dice rolls, we have always used the uniform probability over all possible configurations. From this, we deduced the independence of the different rolls.
The reasoning usually goes the other way. Let Ω={1,2,3,4,5,6}n\Omega=\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}^n and the XiX_i be the coordinate random variables. It is usually reasonable to assume that the XiX_i are independent, and that their law is uniform on {1,2,3,4,5,6}\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}. They are hence i.i.d. variables. This determines the probability on Ω\Omega: P({ω=(ω1,...,ωn)})=P(X1,...,Xn)({ω=(ω1,...,ωn)})=∏PXi({ωi})=16n.\begin{aligned} P(\{\omega=(\omega_1,...,\omega_n)\}) &=& P_{(X_1,...,X_n)}(\{\omega=(\omega_1,...,\omega_n)\})\\ &=& \prod P_{X_i}(\{\omega_i \}) = \frac{1}{6^n}.\\\end{aligned}

Hence PP is uniform.

Definition 16 (Expectation).

Idea


Let Ω={1,2}\Omega=\{1,2\} with P({1})=110P(\{1\})=\frac{1}{10} and P({2})=910P(\{2\})=\frac{9}{10}. Let XX be a real random variable, X:Ω→ℝX:\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}. For each elementary configuration ω\omega, XX takes the value X(ω)X(\omega). The ’expectation’ of XX is the ’average’ value of the X(ω)X(\omega) with respect to the probabilities of the {ω}\{\omega\}. In our example:

𝔼(X)=X(1).P({1})+X(2).P({2})=1×110+2×910.\mathbb{E}(X) = X(1).P(\{1\}) + X(2).P(\{2\}) = 1\times \frac{1}{10} + 2\times \frac{9}{10}.

Definition


If Ω=ℤ\Omega=\mathbb{Z}, the average of a random variable X:Ω→ℝX:\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R} becomes:

𝔼(X)=∑i∈ΩX(i)×P({i}).\mathbb{E}(X) = \sum_{i\in\Omega} X(i)\times P(\{i\}).

Now consider the case Ω=ℝ\Omega=\mathbb{R}, with a probability PP of density ff. The formula for the expectation becomes (when the integral exists)

𝔼(X)=∫−∞+∞X(ω)f(ω)dω.\mathbb{E}(X) = \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} X(\omega) f(\omega)d\omega.

There is a definition of the expectation which does not depend on the nature of Ω\Omega and PP. The expectation (average / mean) of XX is defined by

𝔼(X)=∫ΩXdP.\mathbb{E}(X) = \int_{\Omega} XdP.

Where the integral is a ’Lebesgue integrals’ (as opposed to Riemann integrals). When Ω\Omega is discrete, the Lebesgue integral becomes a sum over Ω\Omega, while when PP has a density, dPdP can be replaced by f(ω)dωf(\omega)d\omega. Lebesgue integrals will not be used in this course, but it is useful to be familiar with this notation.

𝔼(X)\mathbb{E}(X) from the law PXP_X


In the discrete case, the previous definition is based on the sum of the X(ω)X(\omega) over all the configurations ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omega, weight by the probabilities P({ω})P(\{\omega\}). The same result can be obtained by summing all the possible values x∈Ex\in E that X(ω)X(\omega) can take, weighted by their probabilities PX({x})P_X(\{x\}).
This approach leads to the following important equalities

  • If E=ℤE=\mathbb{Z}, we have that

    𝔼(X)=∑i∈ℤi.PX({i}).\mathbb{E}(X) = \sum_{i\in \mathbb{Z}} i.P_X(\{i\}).

  • If E=ℝE=\mathbb{R} and if the law PXP_X has a density fXf_X, we have

    𝔼(X)=∫−∞+∞xfX(x)dx\mathbb{E}(X)= \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} xf_X(x)dx

Exercise: Prove the result when X:ℤ→ℤX:\mathbb{Z}\rightarrow \mathbb{Z}.

Linearity


The set of random variables X:Ω→ℝX:\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R} is a vector space ((X+Y)(ω)=X(ω)+Y(ω)(X+Y)(\omega)=X(\omega)+Y(\omega)). The set of random variables such that 𝔼(X)=∫ΩXdP\mathbb{E}(X)=\int_{\Omega} XdP exists is again a vector space. Since integrals are linear, the expectation 𝔼:L1(Ω)→ℝ\mathbb{E}:L^1(\Omega)\rightarrow \mathbb{R}

X↦𝔼(X)=∫ΩXdPX \mapsto \mathbb{E}(X)=\int_{\Omega} XdP

is a linear application valued in ℝ\mathbb{R} (i.e. a linear form). In other words, we have the fundamentals properties:

𝔼(αX)=α𝔼(X) and 𝔼(X+Y)=𝔼(X)+𝔼(Y).\mathbb{E}(\alpha X) = \alpha \mathbb{E}(X) \quad \text{ and } \quad \mathbb{E}(X+Y) = \mathbb{E}(X) + \mathbb{E}(Y).

We have the important equality v(X)=𝔼(X2)−𝔼(X)2.v(X)=\mathbb{E}(X^2)-\mathbb{E}(X)^2.

Definition


In general, the adjective ’empirical’ is understood as ’coming from observations’, as opposed to a computation made on the configuration space Ω\Omega. Assume that performing a certain experiment lead to the observation of nn numbers xix_i, modeled by random variables XiX_i. The mean of a particular observation is x1+...+xnn.\frac{x_1+...+x_n}{n}.

X‾n\bar X_n is called the ’empirical mean’.

By linearity, the expectation of X‾n\bar X_n is given by 𝔼(X‾n)=𝔼(X1)+...+𝔼(Xn)n.\mathbb{E}(\bar X_n)=\frac{\mathbb{E}(X_1)+...+\mathbb{E}(X_n)}{n}.

Link with expectation


The notion of empirical mean has connections but is different from the notion of expectation, which is a mean over configurations from Ω\Omega. Remember that when Ω\Omega has a uniform probability over a finite numbers of element, 𝔼(X)=∑i=1|Ω|X(ωi)|Ω|.\mathbb{E}(X) = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{|\Omega|}X(\omega_i)}{|\Omega|}.

Hence,

  • the empirical mean is its self a random variable, computed as a sum over different random variables.

  • the expectation is a number, computed for a single random variable, as a sum over configurations ω∈Ω\omega\in \Omega.

Theorem 6 ((Weak) Law of large numbers).

Statement of the theorem


We are now ready state an important result of the theory of probabilities, relating empirical means and expectations.

Let X1,...,Xn,...X_1,...,X_n,... be an infinite sequence i.i.d real random variables of mean μ\mu. Let X‾n\bar X_n be the empirical mean X‾n=X1+..+Xnn.\bar X_n = \frac{X_1+..+X_n}{n}. For all ϵ>0\epsilon>0, we have P(|X‾n−μ|>ϵ)=P({ω∈Ω||X‾n(ω)−μ|>ϵ})→n→∞0.P(|\bar X_n-\mu |>\epsilon)=P(\{\omega \in \Omega |\quad |\bar X_n(\omega) - \mu |>\epsilon\})\xrightarrow[n\rightarrow \infty]{} 0.

In simple words: when nn is large the values of X‾n\bar X_n are almost always close to μ\mu.

Idea of the proof


We will not prove this result, but it can be intuitively understood in a simple way when the variable have variances. First, note that 𝔼(X‾)=𝔼(X1)=μ\mathbb{E}(\bar X)=\mathbb{E}(X_1)=\mu. Then, remember that v(X‾n=1n∑iXi)→n→∞0.v\left(\bar X_n=\frac{1}{n}\sum_i X_i\right)\xrightarrow[n\rightarrow \infty]{} 0. Hence the law of the empirical mean X‾n\bar X_n is more and more concentrated around its expectation μ\mu, which means that the probability P(|X‾n−μ|>ϵ)P(|\bar X_n-\mu |>\epsilon) should be smaller and smaller.

Probabilities

Configurations and probabilities

Exercise 1 (Reminders of set theory).

  • Enumerate all the elements of {1,2,3}\{1,2,3\}.

  • Enumerate all the subsets of {1,2,3}\{1,2,3\}.

  • Recall what is the Cartesian product of 22 sets.

  • Enumerate all the elements of {1,2}2\{1,2\}^2.

  • Enumerate all the subsets of {1,2}2\{1,2\}^2.

  • Enumerate all the elements of {1}×{1,2}\{1\}\times \{1,2\}

  • Enumerate all the subsets of {1}×{1,2}\{1\}\times \{1,2\}

Exercise 2 (Reminders on combinatorics).

Q1: permutations


Let 𝒮\mathcal{S} be a set of nn elements. We call σ:𝒮→𝒮\sigma:\mathcal{S}\rightarrow \mathcal{S} a permutation when it is a bijection. How many different permutation σ\sigma can we construct?

Q2: drawing objects from a box


Assume that the elements of 𝒮\mathcal{S} are nn physical objects contained in a box. Draw successively kk element from the box, without looking in the box, and without putting the element back before taking the next one. If we remember the order in which we take the elements, how many different configurations can we obtain? If we don’t remember the order in which the different elements were taken, how many different configurations can we obtain?

Remark 1 (Introductory remark).

General remark: in most situations the word probability refers to a proportion.

For instance, the question

"what is the probability of this event?" \text{ "what is the probability of this event?" }

can usually be interpreted as

"what is the proportion of possible configurations in which this event occurs?" \text{ "what is the proportion of possible configurations in which this event occurs?" }

Definition 1 (Configuration space / universe).

Definition


  • The configuration space is usually denoted Ω\Omega. As indicated by its name, the set Ω\Omega contains all the possible configurations of a probabilistic model.

  • Its elements are usually denoted ω\omega, and we will call them ’elementary configurations’.

Warning : the name of the space Ω\Omega and its elements ω\omega vary according to contexts and languages. Ω\Omega is often called the ’sample space’ or ’universe’, and the elements ω\omega ’samples’,’outcomes’ or ’realizations’.

Examples (1)


Probabilistic models are very useful to analyse dice rolls and card games. What is a relevant configuration space

  • to model a dice roll ?

  • to model 22 dice rolls ?

  • to model nn dice rolls ? What is the size of this configuration space?

Examples (2)


Assume that 𝒮\mathcal{S} is a 5252 card deck and that we are interested in modeling an experiment where a player draws cards from the card game. What should we chose as configuration space when

  • the player draws one card ?

  • the player draws one card, puts it back and draws another card ?

  • the player draws two cards without putting them back ?

Assume a player draws nn cards without putting them back in the deck. What is the size of the smallest configuration space describing the possible results ?

Note that when using Cartesian products, we have (a,b)≠(b,a)(a,b)\neq (b,a). The order between the card draws is taken into account. In card games, the order in which cards are drawn is often not important. In that case, when drawing 22 cards, we have (a,b)∼(b,a)(a,b)\sim (b,a).

If we do not distinguish results up to permutations, what is the size of the configuration space when

  • the player draws one card ?

  • the player draws nn cards without putting them back ?

Examples (3)


In this course we are particularly interested in signal and image processing problems.

What are the relevant configuration spaces when studying

  • real signals observed on 10001000 points ?

  • continuous real signals of duration 11 second ?

  • 256×256256\times 256 color images ?

Definition 2 (Events).

Definition


An event AA is a subset of the configuration space Ω\Omega: A⊂ΩA\subset \Omega.

Remark: a more precise definition requires the notion of σ\sigma-algebra. The next ’Remark’ node gives the definition of σ\sigma-algebras, but the notion will not be used in the rest of the course.

Examples


  • for the dice roll, the configuration space is Ω={1,2,3,4,5,6}\Omega = \{1,2,3,4,5,6\}, the subset A={2,4,6}A=\{2,4,6\} is an event. AA is often defined as ’the number is even’.

  • when Ω\Omega is a 5252 card deck, ’the card is a diamond’, ’the card is a 22’, are typical events.

  • when Ω=ℝ1000\Omega=\mathbb{R}^{1000} is a set of signals, the event {0}×ℝ999\{0\}\times \mathbb{R}^{999} describes all the signals starting with 00.

Remark 2 (Events and σ\sigma-algebra).

Introduction


Earlier, events have been defined as subsets A⊂ΩA\subset \Omega. When Ω\Omega is not a finite set, some mathematical problems can appear, and not every subset A⊂ΩA\subset \Omega is considered to be an event. For instance when Ω=ℝ\Omega = \mathbb{R}, events are subsets of ℝ\mathbb{R} which can be constructed ’easily’ from intervals. For instance A=⋃i∈ℕ[i2,i+12]A= \bigcup_{i\in \mathbb{N}} \left[\frac{i}{2},\frac{i+1}{2}\right] is an event. Its probability is given by the sum of P([i2,i+12])P\left([\frac{i}{2},\frac{i+1}{2}]\right). On the other hand, it is possible to define complicated sets which cannot be expressed from intervals. Using the axioms of probability, we cannot compute the probability of such sets from the probability of intervals. Hence we exclude them from events.

Definition


The events are the subsets of Ω\Omega on which we define probability values. The set of events is called the σ\sigma-algebra. In order to be consistent with the probability calculus, the σ\sigma-algebra 𝒜\mathcal{A} on Ω\Omega must satisfy the following axioms:

  • Ω∈𝒜\Omega \in \mathcal{A} (→\rightarrow axiom 1 of probabilities)

  • A∈𝒜⇒Ac∈𝒜A \in \mathcal{A} \Rightarrow A^{c}\in \mathcal{A} (→\rightarrow consequence 1 of probabilities)

  • if Ai∈𝒜A_i\in \mathcal{A} for i∈ℕi\in \mathbb{N}, then ⋃i∈ℕAi∈𝒜\bigcup_{i\in \mathbb{N}} A_i \in \mathcal{A} (→\rightarrow axiom 3 of probabilities)

Examples


  • When Ω\Omega is finite the σ\sigma-algebra is usually 𝒫(Ω)\mathcal{P}(\Omega): every subset of Ω\Omega is an event.

  • when Ω=ℝ\Omega= \mathbb{R}, the σ\sigma-algebra is obtained by taking countable unions of intervals and their complements.

Remark 3 (Assignment of probabilities).
To model real life situations, we assign probabilities to events that reflect what we know about the situation. The probabilities on the configuration space Ω\Omega are usually assigned according to one of the two following principles.

  • Indistinguishability. Assume that in a certain experiment, the elements of Ω\Omega are perfectly indistinguishable. The probability of an event AA is then given by the number of configuration kk in which it occurs (ω∈A\omega \in A) divided by the total number of configuration nn: kn\frac{k}{n}. It is for instance the case when we draw a card from a card game without seeing what is on the card: they are all indistinguishable.

  • Probabilities as frequencies. Assume that an experiment that produces output value in Ω\Omega has been repeated nn times. If kk of the output values belongs to the event AA, the probability assigned to AA is the number kn\frac{k}{n}. This can be used to evaluate the probabilities of the outcomes of an asymmetrical die. We will come back to the link between probabilities and frequencies later in the course.

Independently from how they are assigned, probability values should verify several rules.

Definition 3 (Probability).

Definition


A probability PP is a function which takes in input an event and returns a positive real number. It must verify the following axioms:

  • axiom 1: P(Ω)=1P(\Omega) = 1

  • axiom 2: P(A⊂Ω)≥0P(A\subset \Omega) \geq 0

  • axiom 3: if A∩B=∅A\cap B=\emptyset then P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B) (also true for countable sums)

Direct consequences:

  • consequence 1:P(Ac)=1−P(A)P(A^c) = 1-P(A)

  • consequence 2 :P(∅)=0P(\emptyset) = 0

  • consequence 3:P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(A∩B)P(A\cup B) = P(A)+P(B)-P(A\cap B)

Interpretation


The probability gives a notion of ’size’ to events. Given that the size of Ω\Omega is 11, the size of events can be interpreted as the proportion they occupy in Ω\Omega. Hence, the PP of probability can also be read as the PP of proportion.

Assume that a die is a perfect cube. All faces are indistinguishable from each other, except for the written number. In this case, it is relevant to assign probabilities according to the indistinguishability principle:

P({1})=16,P({2})=16,P({3})=16,P(\{1\}) = \frac{1}{6}, P(\{2\}) = \frac{1}{6},P(\{3\}) = \frac{1}{6}, P({4})=16,P({5})=16,P({6})=16.P(\{4\}) = \frac{1}{6},P(\{5\}) = \frac{1}{6},P(\{6\}) = \frac{1}{6}.

The distribution is called uniform. It is now possible to compute the probability of every event, using the axiom 3 (if A∩B=∅A\cap B=\emptyset then P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B)):

P({2,4,6})=P({2}∪{4}∪{6})=P({2})+P({4})+P({6})=12.P\left(\{2,4,6\}\right) = P\left(\{2\}\cup\{4\}\cup \{6\}\right)=P(\{2\})+P(\{4\})+P(\{6\})=\frac{1}{2}.

Assume now that our die is a bit damaged. It is no longer perfectly symmetrical. Hence, we can no longer use the principle of indistinguishability. In that case a relevant approach is to roll the die many time and to assign probabilities according to the frequency of apparition of the numbers.

P({1})=k1N,P({2})=k2N,P({3})=k3N,P(\{1\}) = \frac{k_1}{N}, P(\{2\}) = \frac{k_2}{N},P(\{3\}) = \frac{k_3}{N}, P({4})=k4N,P({5})=k5N,P({6})=k6N.P(\{4\}) = \frac{k_4}{N},P(\{5\}) = \frac{k_5}{N},P(\{6\}) = \frac{k_6}{N}.

Exactly as before, the probability of other events is calculated with the rule ’if A∩B=∅A\cap B=\emptyset then P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B)’.

Definition 4 (Probability density).

Let PP be a probability on ℝ\mathbb{R}. We say that the function ff is the probability density of PP when

∀A∈ℝ,P(A)=∫Af(x)dx.\forall A\in \mathbb{R},\quad P(A)=\int_A f(x)\mathrm{d}x.

Note that PP does not always have a density. Take for instance PP such that P({0})=1P(\{0\})=1: there are no functions ff verifying the above condition.

Exercise 3 (Gaussian densities (1D1D)).

  • What condition must verify a function f:ℝ→ℝf:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R} to be interpreted as a probability density?
    It can be proved that the standardized Gaussian function has integral 11: ∫−∞+∞12πe−x22dx=1.\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{\frac{-x^2}{2}}dx=1.

  • What can we say about fμ,σ(x)=12πσ2e−(x−μ)22σ2?f_{\mu,\sigma}(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi \sigma^2}}e^{\frac{-(x-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}} \quad?

Random Variables

Definition 5 (Random variables).

Introduction


Introduce first the idea behind the definition. Build a configuration space representing the possible ages of 22 persons. A natural choice is Ω=ℝ×ℝ\Omega = \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R} where the first coordinate represents the possible ages of the first person,and the second represents the possible ages of the second person (Ω=ℝ+×ℝ+\Omega = \mathbb{R}_+ \times \mathbb{R}_+ is also a natural choice).

The coordinate function age1:Ω→ℝage_1:\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R},

age1(ω=(ω1,ω2))=ω1age_1\left(\omega=(\omega_1,\omega_2)\right)=\omega_1

’extracts’ the age of the first person out of an elementary configuration ω\omega. Similarly, the coordinate function age2:Ω→ℝage_2:\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R},

age2(ω=(ω1,ω2))=ω2age_2\left(\omega=(\omega_1,\omega_2)\right)=\omega_2

’extracts’ the age of the second person. The functions age1age_1 and age2age_2 are called random variables.
The coordinates functions age1age_1 and age2age_2 extract interesting quantities from the elementary configuration. However, there are other interesting quantities which are not coordinate functions. For instance, for an elementary configuration ω\omega, we can be interested in the average age of the 22 persons. We can define the function average:Ω→ℝaverage:\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R},

average(ω=(ω1,ω2))=ω1+ω22average\left(\omega=(\omega_1,\omega_2)\right) = \frac{\omega_1+\omega_2}{2}

The function averageaverage is also called a random variable.

Definition


A random variable XX taking values in a space EE is a function X:Ω→EX:\Omega\rightarrow E. In particular, integer random variables are functions X:Ω→ℕX:\Omega\rightarrow \mathbb{N} and real random variables are functions X:Ω→ℝX:\Omega\rightarrow \mathbb{R}.

Remark: this is a simplified version of the true definition which requires random variables to be ’measurable functions’ that is to say : when AA is in the σ\sigma-algebra of EE, X−1(A)X^{-1}(A) must be in the σ\sigma-algebra of Ω\Omega.

Example 1


Consider the following dice rolling game. If the number is even, the player wins 11 euro, and if the number is odd he loses 11 euro. The function Gain:Ω={1,2,3,4,5,6}→{−1,1}Gain:\Omega=\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}\rightarrow \{-1,1\}, G(1)=G(3)=G(5)=−1G(1)=G(3)=G(5)=-1 G(2)=G(4)=G(6)=1G(2)=G(4)=G(6)=1 is a random variable.

Example 2: coordinate random variables


Assume that we roll a dice nn times. The configuration space that describes all the possible outcomes is Ω={1,2,3,4,5,6}n\Omega = \{1,2,3,4,5,6\}^n. Let XiX_i be the ii-th coordinate function on Ω\Omega. For instance,

X1((3,2,3,...,6))=3.X_1\left( (3,2,3,...,6) \right) = 3. These random variables ’extract’ the result of the ii-th roll out of the elementary configuration. We can also construct the random variables Gaini=Gain∘XiGain_i = Gain \circ X_i: the gain at the ii-th roll.

Definition 6 (Law of a random variables).

Introduction


Let Ω\Omega be a configuration space with a probability PP, and XX be a random variable taking values in a set EE. Recall that PP is a function that takes in input an event of Ω\Omega and associates its probability. The random variable transports the probability PP to the set EE. The probability of a set AA in EE is determined by the probability of the inverse image of AA in Ω\Omega.

Definition


The law of PXP_X of the random variable X:Ω→EX:\Omega \rightarrow E is a probability on EE defined by PX(A⊂E)=P(X−1(A)).P_X(A \subset E) = P\left(X^{-1}(A)\right). It is called the law of the random variable XX.
Remarks:

  • instead of PX(A)P_X(A), we often write P(X∈A)P(X\in A) (the probability that the value of the random variable XX falls in AA).

  • EE can be viewed as another configuration space with a probability PXP_X

In the previous game, the random variable Gain:Ω={1,2,3,4,5,5}→{−1,1}Gain:\Omega=\{1,2,3,4,5,5\}\rightarrow \{-1,1\}, Gain(1)=Gain(3)=Gain(5)=−1Gain(1)=Gain(3)=Gain(5)=-1 Gain(2)=Gain(4)=Gain(6)=1Gain(2)=Gain(4)=Gain(6)=1 induces a probability distribution on {−1,1}\{-1,1\}. We have PGain({−1})=P(Gain−1({−1}))=P({1})+P({3})+P({5})P_{Gain}(\{-1\}) = P(Gain^{-1}(\{-1\}))=P(\{1\})+P(\{3\})+P(\{5\}) PGain({1})=P(Gain−1({1}))=P({2})+P({4})+P({6}).P_{Gain}(\{1\}) = P(Gain^{-1}(\{1\}))=P(\{2\})+P(\{4\})+P(\{6\}).

Definition: cumulative distribution


Let XX be a real random variable (E=ℝE=\mathbb{R}). The probability PXP_X can be represented by its cumulative distribution FX:ℝ→ℝF_X:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}, defined by

FX(a)=PX(]−∞,a]).F_X(a) = P_X\left(]-\infty,a]\right).

All the information on PXP_X is contained in FXF_X. Since the cumulative distribution is a function ℝ→ℝ\mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}, sometimes it is conceptually simpler to manipulate FXF_X than the probability itself which is a function from the subsets of ℝ\mathbb{R} to ℝ\mathbb{R}.

  • How do we compute PX(]a,b])P_X(]a,b]) from FXF_X?

  • What do we know about limx→∞FX(x)\lim_{x\rightarrow \infty} F_X(x) ?

  • Can we have x<yx<y and FX(x)>FX(y)F_X(x)>F_X(y)?

  • If for x∈[0,1]x\in [0,1], FX(x)=xF_X(x)=x, what is PX([2,3])P_X([2,3])?

Definition: density of a real random variable


Let XX be a real random variable. Sometimes, the law of XX admits a density. When it exists, the density of XX is a function fXf_X such that

PX([a,b])=∫abfX(x)dx.P_X([a,b]) = \int_a^b f_X(x)dx.

Remark: we defined the cumulative distribution and density of a ’random variable’ but note that it depends on XX only through the probability PXP_X. Hence the density can be defined for a probability PP on ℝ\mathbb{R} even if it is not defined as the law of a random variable.

Exercises


For a real random variable XX,

  • show that ∫−∞+∞fX(x)dx=1\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}f_X(x)dx=1

  • show that fX=(FX)′f_X=(F_X)'.

Definition 7 (Joint random variables).

Definition


Consider 22 random variables X:Ω→EX:\Omega \rightarrow E and Y:Ω→FY:\Omega \rightarrow F. The random variable Z:Ω→E×FZ:\Omega \rightarrow E\times F,

Z=(X,Y)Z=(X,Y)

is called the joint random variable. The law PZ=P(X,Y)P_{Z}=P_{(X,Y)} of ZZ is called the joint law (or joint probability distribution).

Examples


Consider the case of nn dice rolls. Let Ω={1,2,3,4,5,6}n\Omega = \{1,2,3,4,5,6\}^n be a configuration space, with the uniform probability distribution PP. Let XiX_i be the ii-th coordinate function. Consider the joint random variable

Z=(X1,..,Xn).Z = (X_1,..,X_n).

What the space of values of ZZ? What is the law of ZZ?

Consider now Z:Ω→{1,2,3,4,5,6}2,Z=(X1,X2).Z:\Omega \rightarrow \{1,2,3,4,5,6\}^2,\quad Z=(X_1,X_2).

What is the law of ZZ?

Exercise 4 (Simple game model).

Consider the following game. A player flips twice a coin. If both flips are heads, the player wins 11 euro. Otherwise he loses 11 euro. Make a probabilistic model which describes the game.

Exercise 5 (Image as random variable).

Let II be a 512×512512\times 512 image valued in {0,1,...,255}\{0,1,...,255\}. II can be viewed as a random variable from the configuration space Ω={0,1,...,511}2→{0,1,...,255}\Omega = \{0,1,...,511\}^2\rightarrow \{0,1,...,255\}. Assume that PP is a uniform probability distribution over Ω\Omega. The law PIP_I of II corresponds to something that we already meet in the image processing course. What is it? What is the formal difference?

Exercise 6 (Simple joint law).

Consider Ω={0,1}2\Omega=\{0,1\}^2 with a uniform probability, and X1X_1 and X2X_2 the coordinate random variables. Let YY and ZZ be two random variables Ω→{0,1,2}\Omega \rightarrow \{0,1,2\} defined by

Y=X1+X2 and Z=X1X2.Y = X_1 + X_2 \text{ and } Z = X_1X_2.

Give the laws of YY, ZZ, and the joint law of (Y,Z)(Y,Z).

Exercise 7 (Sums of equiprobable 0s and 1s).

Theory


Consider the configuration space Ω={0,1}n\Omega = \{ 0,1 \}^n (Ω\Omega can be interpreted as the vertices of an hypercube), with the uniform probability distribution. What is the cardinal of Ω\Omega ?
Consider now the random variable X:Ω→{0,..,n}X:\Omega \rightarrow \{0,..,n\}, X((ω1,...,ωn))=∑i=1nωi,X((\omega_1,...,\omega_n)) = \sum_{i=1}^n \omega_i, which counts the number of 11 in each nn-tuple. What is the law of the random variable XX?

Application: probability of a binary image


Propose a very simple probabilistic model over the set of binary images of size 256×256256\times 256. What can we say about the probability that

  • an image contains only 11s (or 00s)?

  • it contains exactly 11 time the number 11?

  • the number of 11 it contains is exactly kk?

  • the number of 11s is smaller or equal to kk?

Remark 4 (Abstract configuration space).

Most probability problems of this course start by defining a configuration space Ω\Omega and a probability PP on it. Though, many real life problems involving probabilities make no mention of the space Ω\Omega.

Example: weather


Assume that we want to predict the wind speed SS in Marseille. Since we know that the wind speed is related to the temperature TT, we can attempt to predict the wind speed from the temperature. The wind speed is a vector of ℝ3\mathbb{R}^3 and the temperature is a positive number, hence our problem can be fully modeled by the configuration space Ω1=ℝ3×ℝ+\Omega_1 = \mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathbb{R}_+. From a database of measurements, we can estimate the probability of an elementary configuration by P1({(s,t)})=n(s,t)nP_1(\{(s,t)\})=\frac{n_{(s,t)}}{n}, where n(s,t)n_{(s,t)} is the number of times (s,t)(s,t) has been measured and nn is the total number of measurements. With the law P1P_1, it is possible to calculate the conditional probability (which we will define later) of the wind speed given the temperature. With this conditional probability, it is possible to say what is the most probable value of wind speed for a temperature.

Now assume that temperature is a poor predictor of wind speed: given a temperature, the probability over wind speed has a high variance. In order to improve our analysis, it is common to incorporate new parameters in our model. We could, for instance consider the atmospheric pressure PrPr. The new configuration space would then be Ω2=ℝ3×ℝ+×ℝ+\Omega_2 = \mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathbb{R}_+ \times \mathbb{R}_+, with probability P2P_2. Luckily, given a temperature and a pressure, the probability on the wind speed has a small variance.

Otherwise, we could incorporate more and more parameters, and consider new configuration spaces. In practice, instead of changing the configuration space each time we want to add a parameter, we treat the parameters as random variables of a larger configuration space. At a given moment, all the meteorological parameters are a function of the positions and speeds of the particles, which could be described by the configuration space Ω=(ℝ3×ℝ3)N\Omega = (\mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathbb{R}^3)^N, where NN is the number of particles. Wind speed, temperature, and air pressure are functions of the type Ω→ℝd\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^d, hence they are random variables.

In practice, evaluating and manipulating a probability PP on the positions and velocities of each particles is unrealistic. Though only the joint law of the studied variables matters, in our case the joint law P(S,T,Pr)P_{(S,T,Pr)} of the random variable (S,T,Pr):Ω→ℝ3×ℝ+×ℝ+(S,T,Pr):\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathbb{R}_+ \times \mathbb{R}_+.
